questions.text: Identify the imaging modality shown here.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an image of USG being performed.

This is a B-mode (brightness mode) ultrasound image, showing soft tissue structures in grayscale. The presence of well-defined, hypoechoic (dark) structures with surrounding echogenic (bright) soft tissues is characteristic of an ultrasound scan. The label "VN" likely refers to a vascular or neural structure.

Other Options:

(B) X-Ray

  • Uses ionizing radiation to capture dense structures like bones.
  • Poor soft tissue contrast, unlike the image provided.

(C) MRI

  • Uses magnetic fields for high-contrast soft tissue imaging.
  • Produces T1, T2, and fat-suppressed images, but lacks the typical ultrasound texture.

(D) Fluoroscopy

  • A real-time X-ray technique using contrast agents.
  • Used for motion studies (e.g., swallowing, angiography).

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 3818

questions.text: This "double bleb sign" seen in early pregnancy is due to?
questions.solution:
The "double bleb sign" is an early ultrasound finding in pregnancy, seen on transvaginal ultrasound around 4.5-6 weeks of gestation. It consists of:

  • The amniotic sac (inner bleb)
  • The yolk sac (outer bleb)

These two sacs appear as two adjacent fluid-filled structures within the gestational sac, separated by the developing embryonic disc.

(A) Heterotopic Pregnancy

  • Heterotopic pregnancy refers to the presence of one intrauterine pregnancy and one ectopic pregnancy (commonly in the fallopian tube).
  • It does not cause the "double bleb sign." Instead, ultrasound shows a normal intrauterine pregnancy along with an adnexal mass or extrauterine gestational sac.

(C) Two Uterine Gestational Sacs

  • This occurs in dichorionic twin pregnancies (twins with separate placentas).
  • Each gestational sac would contain its own structures, but they wouldn't create the single double-bleb appearance seen in early pregnancy.

(D) Amnion & Chorion

  • The amnion (inner fetal membrane) and chorion (outer fetal membrane) fuse around 14-16 weeks of gestation.
  • The "double bleb sign" is seen much earlier, at 5-6 weeks, when the yolk sac and amniotic sac are visible together.

Reference: Clinical Ultrasound, Volume 3, page no 156

questions.text: Best time to detect chorionicity & amnionicity of pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
The best time to determine chorionicity (number of placentas) and amnionicity (number of amniotic sacs) is in the first trimester (between 6-13 weeks) using ultrasound, as the findings are most distinct early in pregnancy.

Key ultrasound markers for determining chorionicity and amnionicity in the first trimester:

  • Lambda (λ) sign → Suggests dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twins (two placentas, two sacs).
  • T-sign → Suggests monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) twins (one placenta, two sacs).
  • Single sac without a separating membrane → Suggests monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) twins (one placenta, one sac).

Other Options:

(B) Second Trimester

  • The placental membranes become thinner and more difficult to distinguish, making it harder to accurately determine chorionicity and amnionicity.

(C) Third Trimester

  • The placental and amniotic membranes may have fused, making chorionicity determination unreliable.
  • Growth discordance or complications (e.g., twin-twin transfusion syndrome in monochorionic twins) may already have developed.

(D) Peripartum (Near Delivery)

  • It is too late to determine chorionicity and amnionicity accurately.
  • By this time, the focus is on fetal presentation, delivery planning, and potential complications.

Reference: Clinical Ultrasound, Volume 3, page no 247

questions.text: First Trimester USG is/are used for?
questions.solution:
The major role of ultrasound in first trimester of pregnancy is to establish the presence of normal live intrauterine pregnancy and to distinguish this form either pregnancy failure or ectopic pregnancy. Pregnancy is also dated accurately in first trimester.

The first trimester scan is also used for screening of anomalies.

Reference: Clinical Ultrasound, Volume 3, page no 153, 281
